ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Aligned CuO nanorod arrays: fabrication and anisotropic ferromagnetism

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Department of Physics and Key Laboratory of MEMS of the Ministry of Education

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Copper oxide (CuO) is a p-type semiconductor with a band gap of 1.2 eV, which is well known in high-temperature superconductor and antiferromagnetic (AFM) materials through Cu–O–Cu super-exchange interaction. In this paper, we report the strong anisotropic ferromagnetism (FM) in aligned CuO nanorod arrays synthesized by a microwave-assisted hydrothermal method. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image shows that the CuO nanorod consists of a large number of smaller nanorods with almost the same growth direction. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern indicates that the CuO nanorods are well crystallized with highly preferred orientation of the [020] direction. These CuO nanorod arrays show room-temperature ferromagnetism, with strong magnetic anisotropy when the magnetic field is applied perpendicular or parallel to the rod axis. This phenomenon of room-temperature ferromagnetism in those aligned CuO nanorods might originate from uncompensated surface spins and shape anisotropy of the nanorods.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: One-dimensional (1D) semiconductor nanostructures have initiated great interest for their importance in basic scientific research and many practical applications, such as gas sensors [1], catalysts [2], dye-sensitized solar cells [3], and photonic and optoelectronic devices [4]. For 1D nanostructures, they possess a particular feature that the growth along one dimension is much faster than the others. It is also an ideal system to explore the properties of the materials’ dependency on their size and dimensionality. The aligned 1D nanostructure arrays, which are highly oriented along one direction, are particularly important to improve the properties of the materials due to the uniform growth direction. So, aligned 1D nanostructure arrays are of great interest and various methods have been developed to fabricate these 1D nanostructure arrays, including wet chemical reaction [5], thermal evaporation [6], sol–gel method [7], laser ablation [8, 9], chemical vapor deposition process [10], template-directed synthesis [11], etc.

CuO is a p-type semiconductor with a band gap of 1.2 eV, which is an antiferromagnetic (AFM) material and well known in high-temperature superconductors. CuO is one of the most fascinating AFM materials through Cu–O–Cu super-exchange interaction, which is important for studying the AFM phenomenon and the high-temperature superconducting property. The dual properties make CuO a novel material in various fields, such as gas sensors, catalysis, electrochemical cells, magnetic storage media [12, 13], and spin-valve devices [14]. When the size of CuO falls into the nanoscale, ferromagnetism (FM) is often observed [15], which is usually explained by intrinsic defects [16], size effect [17], and the uncompensated exchange couplings at the surface of CuO nanostructures [18]. The surface of AFM nanostructures actually leads to a breaking of the sublattice pairing and thus produces uncompensated surface spins, which brings the appearance of a net magnetic moment. As the size of the AFM nanostructures decreases, the significance of the surface spins increases. For example, the exchange anisotropy has been investigated in CuO nanowires prepared by thermal oxidation of Cu [19]. This exchange bias is explained by a model of an AFM nanowire core surrounded by a spin-glass-like shell associated with uncompensated surface spins. Room-temperature ferromagnetism has also been observed in pure copper oxide [20–23]. The origin is proposed to be oxygen vacancies at the surface or interface of the particles [23]. However, few works reported the magnetism of aligned 1D CuO nanostructure arrays, possibly due to the absence of a synthesis method to produce well-ordered CuO nanorod arrays. Especially, as far as we know, the anisotropic magnetism in 1D CuO nanostructure arrays has not been investigated yet. In this paper, we employed a microwave heating method to obtain aligned CuO nanorods. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern points out that the CuO nanorods are well crystallized with preferred orientation of the [020] direction. Magnetic measurements indicate that the CuO nanorod arrays show room-temperature ferromagnetism, with strong magnetic anisotropy when the magnetic field is applied perpendicular or parallel to the rod axis.

Section1.Heading: Experimental section
Section1.Para: The growth of CuO nanorods was carried out by a CuO nanoseed-mediated growth method on a Si (100) substrate. This Si wafer was first coated with a CuO layer (about 50 nm) by pulsed laser deposition (PLD). Then aligned CuO nanorod arrays were prepared by dipping this substrate in a mixture of 12.5 mM copper nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O) and 25 mM hexamethylenetetramine (HMTA, C6H12N4) solutions in deionized water and by heating in a commercially available microwave oven (Galanz, 2.45 GHz). This heating process was performed for 20 min with a power of 640 W to grow the CuO nanorod arrays with length of ∼460 nm. For the purpose of comparison, samples were also synthesized by a hydrothermal method in a water bath [24]. The experimental process is the same as that of the above method except for the heating method and the growth time. In the synthesis process, the coated substrate was put into the mixed solution and grown for 4 h in the water bath.

The morphology and size of CuO nanorods were characterized by field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, Ultra Plus, Zeiss) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Tecnai G2 F20). The crystal structure of the CuO nanorods was measured by an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, Smartlab, Rigaku) with Cu-K α radiation (λ=0.15406 nm). The magnetization measurements were performed using a vibrating sample magnetometer integrated in a physical property measurement system (PPMS-9, Quantum Design) at room temperature.

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
Figure 1 presents the typical FESEM image to show the cross section and top view of cleaved CuO nanorod arrays on the Si (100) substrate. The thickness of CuO nanoseeds is about 50 nm. On the top of these nanoseeds, vertically aligned CuO nanorods are observed. It can be seen that the CuO nanorods consist of small rod-like nanocrystals with sharp tips. The length is ∼460 nm. The FESEM image of CuO nanorod arrays prepared by the hydrothermal method is inserted as the inset of Fig. 1, in which similar morphology can be observed. Figure 2 shows the energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectrum of the CuO nanorods prepared by the microwave heating method. In addition to the Si peak which comes from the Si (100) substrate, only peaks corresponding to elements Cu and O are observed, pointing out that no other impurity can be detected in the grown sample.
Fig. 1
FESEM image of CuO nanorods prepared by microwave heating method on Si (100) wafer. Inset is the FESEM image of the sample synthesized by hydrothermal method
Fig. 2
EDX spectrum of the CuO nanorods

The magnetization (M) versus magnetic field (H) curves of the CuO nanorods at room temperature (RT) of 305 K are shown in Fig. 4. The M–H curve of the pure Si substrate is presented in the inset of Fig. 4a, appearing as a weak diamagnetism of ∼0.03 emu/cm3. Curves in Fig. 4a and b correspond to the samples synthesized by the microwave heating method and the hydrothermal approach in a water bath, respectively. The paramagnetic (PM) and AFM signals from the sample and the substrate were deducted. From Fig. 4, room-temperature ferromagnetism is obviously observed. The saturated magnetizations (M S) with applied magnetic field perpendicular (M S⊥) or parallel (M S∥) to the substrate are quite different for the same sample. It is clearly observed that M S∥ of the samples is much greater than M S⊥, showing a strong anisotropic magnetization (Fig. 4). This means that the easy direction of magnetization is perpendicular to the nanorods, for the nanorods are aligned to the substrate.
Fig. 4
M–H loops of the samples at 305 K with applied magnetic field parallel (∥) or perpendicular (⊥) to the Si (100) substrate, respectively. (a) and (b) show the samples synthesized by the microwave heating method and the hydrothermal approach in a water bath, respectively. Inset is the M–H curve of the pure Si substrate

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: One-dimensional aligned CuO nanorod arrays were obtained by a microwave heating approach. This method can be used to grow vertically oriented CuO nanorods on various substrates. The XRD spectrum identifies these CuO nanorods as single phase with highly preferred growth along the [020] direction. These as-prepared 1D CuO nanorod arrays exhibit room-temperature ferromagnetism with strong anisotropic ferromagnetism when the magnetic field is applied perpendicular or parallel to the rod axis. The magnetic anisotropy is also observed from CuO nanorods fabricated by the hydrothermal method. This phenomenon is possibly explained because the easy growth direction of these CuO nanorods is different from the easy axis of the magnetization.
